When doing [Help]>[Software updates]>[Find and Install...] Eclipse locks up, and the IDE is unresponsive (hour glass when the mouse moves across it, etc).

There is no java core dump (that I can find), and no entries are written to the log file - verified by clearing the log first.

The only way to 'recover' is to use TaskManager to kill the Eclipse process.

This is with Eclipse build I20051102-1600 (3.2 M3 I think)

Same thing here, except Eclipse "recovers" 25-30 secs later and displays the ensuing dialog. Meanwhile eclipse.exe takes full CPU resources. Subsequent "Find and Install.." invocations work fine. The first attempt in a loaded workspace is the issue.

Another me too! A point that may be relevant is that I'm behind a NTLM proxy. I've tried using the proxy directly and ntlmaps.

OS: Win XP professional
JDK: 1.4.2.12, 1.5.0_08, 1.6.0.b2 (happens on all of them)
Eclipse: M20060629-1905

Nothing is written to the console log (using the -consoleLog flag). Looking at the stack trace (attached) it may have something to do with the "lookupAllHostAddr" call.

Same problem for me. Eclipse hangs a lot.
I'm working behind a HTTP Proxy too.

I'm experiencing the same behaviour.

I'm running:
* Eclipse 3.1.2 (Build id: M20060921-0945)
* on Windows XP 
* over my company's VPN 
* and through a Proxy Server.
* I let it run for 5 minutes and experienced none of the "timeout/only first time's a problem" like others.

I've used the [Software updates] > [Find and Install...] before in the office through my company's proxy server but never from home through both VPN and Proxy Server.  After reading the comments I dropped off VPN and and removed the proxy server settings (now going with just my ISP) I was able to access the Find and install.

I'll have to try again from the office (with Proxy but not VPN) to see if something is permanently broken in my install or if it's the combination of VPN and Proxy.

So, if you have the luxury, the workaround might be to get a hold of a an internet connection that does not need a proxy server to perform the updates.

BTW: I found that the [Sofware Updates] > [Manage Configuration] still works over proxy so it's only a matter of getting the plugin the first time and then using the "Scan for Updates".

I am running Java 1.5.0_10. I will try upgrading to the latest version of Java 1.5 to see if it changes anything.

It looks like this is caused by a badly configured DNS (in my case a host that does not actually run a DNS server is configured in DNS settings). Looks like Java >=1.5 does not like this setup. More information about this can be found here:
http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=5092063

I have the same problem when running eclipse with a 1.5 VM - it takes about 5 minutes till the next dialog opens. When starting eclipse with a 1.6 VM it takes about 30 seconds, which is much faster, but also annoying.  I suppose it's because of my company's proxy.

I have two suggestions about how to handle this:

1 - inform the user what's happening: open a dialog and inform the user that a network connection has to be made now. Then one would know what's happening and why she has to wait now.

2 - no modal dialog: open a dialog (like when building) that enables you to send this task to the background.  It's OK to wait if I can work in the meantime.
